author: FE Online
title: Uttar Pradesh Elections 2017: Nizamabad constituency; SP’s Alambadi Aazmi takes on BSP’s Chandra Dev Ram; All you need to know
text:
Uttar pradesh assembly elections 2017 Uttar Pradesh Elections 2017: Nizamabad constituency; SP’s Alambadi Aazmi takes on BSP’s Chandra Dev Ram; All you need to know Uttar Pradesh Elections 2017: Nizamabad constituency; SP’s Alambadi Aazmi takes on BSP’s Chandra Dev Ram; All you need to know Nizamabad is constituency No. 348 of Uttar Pradesh legislative assembly. It comes under Lalganj Lok Sabha constituency. It is an open constituency. The corresponding Lok Sabha constituency Lalganj is reserved for scheduled castes. By: FE Online | Published: February 23, 2017 1:16 PM Nizamabad is constituency No. 348 of Uttar Pradesh legislative assembly. It comes under Lalganj Lok Sabha constituency. It is an open constituency. The corresponding Lok Sabha constituency Lalganj is reserved for scheduled castes. (Source: PTI) 
Voting for the fourth phase of the Uttar Pradesh Assembly elections started today in 53 constituencies spread over 12 districts. Fate of more than 650 candidates will be decided by 1.84 cr voters. Districts such as Raebareli, Mahoba, Hamirpur, Allahabad, Jalaun, Jhansi, Lalitpur, Pratapgarh, Kaushambi, Banda, Chitrakoot and Fatehpur are going to polls in this round. Around 25 per cent of voter turnout has been recorded till afternoon and electorates are coming in good numbers to exercise their voting franchise. Now, the the elections have drove into mid-stage and stakes are high for all major political parties including the Samajwadi Party (SP), Bharatiya Janata Party ( BJP ), Congress and Bahujan Samaj Party (BSP). For SP, phase 4 is most crucial as the ruling party holds 24 out of the 53 seats here. UP, over the past few months, has witnessed high-decibel election rallies and roadshows with all parties leaving no stone unturned to lure voters across the state. While the ongoing polls are touted to be a litmus test for SP, PM Narendra Modi -led BJP has made the road tough for the Akhilesh Yadav -led camp. The incumbent CM has managed to build an image of ‘leader for youth’ and have bagged huge vote bank in various regions of the state. His ‘kaam bolta hai’ campaign has gathered good response in rural as well as the urban areas of the state. However, there has been a little anger ire against him as some believe that he is the reason behind the failure of law-and-order in the state. 
Mayawati-led Bahujan Samaj Party (BSP) has made this election a crucial three-way contest. The party has cemented itself as one of lead contenders in this political run. However, BSP is still running short on numbers as compared to SP and the BJP apart from some particular communities. Even the Muslim community is supporting her in limited areas where the candidates fielded are very strong. This high-voltage assembly elections will lay the cornerstone for the 2019 Lok Sabha elections. While SP aims at retaining its power, this time with the Congress, both BJP and BSP are fighting to make a comeback. 
Nizamabad is constituency No. 348 of Uttar Pradesh legislative assembly. It is situated in Azamgarh district in Purvanchal region of the state. It comes under Lalganj Lok Sabha constituency. It is an open constituency. The corresponding Lok Sabha constituency Lalganj is reserved for scheduled castes. 
Total number of voters As per the Election Commission data, Nizamabad has a total of 2,90,045 registered voters in Nizamabad constituency out of which 1,59,413 are male and 1,30,632 are female registered voters. 
What are the key issues Development is the key issue in this constituency. 
Who was the winner last time SP defeated the BSP convincingly by a margin of 23,843 votes in the 2012 Assembly elections. Alambadi Aazmi who won from SP bagged 63,894 votes followed by Kalamuddin Khan of BSP who got 40,051 votes. The voter turnout was 52.22 per cent. 
You might also want to see this: 
Who are the competing candidates Alambadi Aazmi (SP), Chandra Dev Ram (BSP), Vinod Kumar Rai (BJP) and Yatinjay Raj (NCP). 
Why this constituency is important? This region is called as the power house for the ruling SP. During the 2012 Assembly elections the ruling party bagged as many as 9 out of the 10 seats of this district. Being a Yadav and Muslim-dominated region, SP has a huge vote bank here. Both BSP and BJP have tried their best to improve their support here and win this time. Please Wait while comments are loading...
